image.altText: A young woman and a man smile for a selfie while sitting in a car.

props.synopsis: After a public campaign, an attorney-general's intervention and a tense inquest, a Tasmanian coroner has found that there was no evidence that a woman deliberately hit and killed her partner Jari Wise with her car.

title.children: Coroner finds no evidence woman deliberately killed partner with car in 2020 and questions 'Jari's law'

image.altText: A red, white and black sign on a lawn that reads, University of Tasmania Sandy Bay

props.synopsis: The University of Tasmania has said there is room to reconsider the location of its new STEM building, in a major walking back of its push to move into Hobart's city centre.

title.children: UTAS to consult students and staff on move into Hobart after STEM building backflip

image.altText: An aerial image of blue ocean and coastal strip of land with dirt tracks

props.synopsis: Another four suspected asylum seekers are detained by authorities after their boat is intercepted off the coast of Broome in Western Australia.

title.children: Four suspected asylum seekers intercepted off WA coast

image.altText: Silhouette of two people standing on flat rocks at night with the sky coloured pin, blue and green

props.synopsis: From Australia to the US — here's how the dazzling lights of the aurora australis and borealis were captured in each hemisphere in a rare spectacle.

title.children: 'Ludicrous': How a confluence of factors created a once-in-a-lifetime aurora

image.altText: A brown and black silhouette of a man's face from the side

props.synopsis: A spy for one of the most feared and powerful arms of China’s intelligence apparatus is revealing his identity and operations overseas, including in Australia, as part of a Four Corners investigation.

title.children: A spy for China's secret police is going public to reveal how people in Australia are targeted

image.altText: A man in glasses and a white t-shirt holds a book out as a younger girl reads aloud and leans into him in their living room.

props.synopsis: Learning to read in his 40s changed Morris' life. Advocates hope the tactic that worked for him will help millions of others and boost literacy rates.

title.children: Once done away with, the importance of phonics to learning to read is back

image.altText: The light plane landed safely at Newcastle Airport just after noon today

props.synopsis: The engines of the Beechcraft Super King Air appeared to power down as it approached the runway at Newcastle airport, landing at 12:18pm and sliding to a stop to the loud cheers of onlookers who had lined the perimeter fence.

title.children: Plane makes emergency landing in Newcastle with three onboard after landing gear fails

image.altText: In a soft-lit reception area with sign reading LASER CLINICS AUSTRALIA, two receptionists stand at a desk

props.synopsis: When franchising works, it works well — but when it doesn't it can be devastating for franchisees and workers. Global cosmetic treatment chain Laser Clinics is shaping up to be another case study in what happens when things go wrong.

title.children: 'It's a complete s***show': Inside the franchising scandal at global cosmetic giant Laser Clinics

image.altText: A row of teenagers sitting down on a long bench chair, all looking at their smartphones

props.synopsis: While keeping kids and teens off social media can work for some, the best choice will depend on your child and your family.

title.children: Why banning your child from social media might not be the best approach

image.altText: Black snake in ute.

props.synopsis: Lisa Kournelis says she was shocked when she first saw the slithery stowaway last month and was forced to wear protective gear to stay safe while driving.

title.children: Woman drives ute with red-bellied black snake onboard after four failed attempts to remove it

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers superimposed over falling leaves from the budget tree and parliament house

props.synopsis: With a federal election fast approaching and Australians struggling with the cost of living, Treasurer Jim Chalmers will have to walk a fine line between caution and courage when he delivers tomorrow's budget.

title.children: Another budget is set to be all about the cost of living, with no easy answers

image.altText: Katy Gallagher and Jim Chalmers walk on the grass on top of Parliament House

props.synopsis: The outlook for Australia's economic growth is worsening and inflation forecasts remain uncertain as the federal government battles to simultaneously spur growth and rein in rising costs.

title.children: Budget forecasts faster inflation drop than expected by RBA as government defends figures

image.altText: A man wearing dark glasses walking outdoors with his head bowed.

props.synopsis: Former Sydney teacher Chris Dawson has launched an appeal against his murder conviction with his legal team arguing his first wife was in despair and chose to leave the family home.

title.children: Appeal team argue Chris Dawson's wife had 'high level of despair' leading up to disappearance and chose to leave

image.altText: A dingo sniffs the sand on K'gari

props.synopsis: Queensland Parks and Wildlife rangers are investigating the death of a dingo on Queensland's heritage-listed island, K'gari. A man allegedly used a speargun to kill the dingo that was lingering around his campsite.

title.children: Dingo allegedly killed with speargun on heritage-listed Queensland island

image.altText: a young boy with a pixelated face gives thumbs up while swimming in a river

props.synopsis: Across Australia there's angst about youth crime, but what do the kids involved think about it? Reporter Erin Parke travelled to the desert to see first hand the hard work and emotional moments involved with trying to "divert" vulnerable kids away from bad behaviour.

title.children: 'We are the naughty kids': At the front line of efforts to stop kids committing crime

image.altText: A composite image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Joe Biden.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden's growing criticism of Israel has left Benjamin Netanyahu having to choose between Israel's strongest supporter, which bankrolls its military, and two far-right politicians.

title.children: Biden's tough words forced Netanyahu to make a choice this week — and he chose two far-right kingmakers

image.altText: A chef in black collared shirt garnishes dishes in a commercial kitchen

props.synopsis: Australian chef Josh Niland served customers fish eyeball crackers to save his failing restaurant. It rocketed his career into the stratosphere and now the world's top chefs can't get enough.

title.children: Australia's Josh Niland is 'one of the most interesting chefs on the planet'. This is his secret ingredient

image.altText: Two South Sydney Rabbitohs NRL players embrace as they celebrate a try.

props.synopsis: The Rabbitohs say they will be assisting the NRL's integrity unit as it looks into allegations of racial abuse directed at Indigenous stars Latrell Mitchell and Cody Walker.

title.children: NRL investigating alleged racial abuse of Latrell Mitchell and Cody Walker

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market ended up going nowhere ahead of tomorrow's federal budget, with new data showing both business conditions and household spending softening last month.

title.children: As it happened: ASX flat as business conditions and household spending fall

image.altText: A black and white photo of a man named Austin Robertson Jr watching a football very closely.

props.synopsis: The daughter of late WA football great Austin Robertson Jr details how her father's confidence was shaken as he battled the effects of CTE, a degenerative brain disease caused by repeated concussions.

title.children: 'His life got quite small': WA footy great's CTE diagnosis confirmed as family details struggle with disease

image.altText: A graphic showing various colourful bubbles imposed over an image of a classroom.

props.synopsis: Australia's university sector is warning against the federal government's plan to cap international student numbers, as a meeting between ministers and the International Education Council is held this morning.

title.children: Peak education bodies warn against government cap on international student numbers

image.altText: man in suit rubbing hands together next to logo of a white x on black background

props.synopsis: The Federal Court has chosen not to extend a temporary order for social media company X, formerly Twitter, to hide videos of a Sydney terrorist stabbing globally.

title.children: eSafety Commissioner loses injunction fight with X over Wakeley stabbing video

image.altText: Baby turtle

props.synopsis: An endangered olive ridley turtle may have travelled close to 2,000 kilometres to nest on Queensland's east coast in a find described by renowned researcher Col Limpus as "quite a phenomenon".

title.children: Turtle travels nearly 2,000km to nest on Queensland coast for first time

image.altText: Convicted child sex offender Allan Hopkins.

props.synopsis: A South Australian man wanted over alleged serious sexual offending involving a child under the age of 18 has been arrested in New South Wales.

title.children: SA man wanted for alleged child sex offences arrested interstate

image.altText: Generic image of two people talking but their faces are not visible

props.synopsis: What happens when a serious offender is released from prison but there's a substantial risk they might re-offend? In Victoria, many of them are housed at Corella Place.

title.children: Why this Victorian residential complex has been dubbed the 'village of the damned'

image.altText: Closeup of hands on a woman wearing purple holding a touch screen phone

props.synopsis: Thousands of perpetrators across Australia are using transactions of "about one cent" to send abusive messages in the description section on online banking platforms.

title.children: How 1-cent transactions are being used to deliver abusive messages

image.altText: Vladimir Putin smiling and gesturing while walking with Sergei Shoigu

props.synopsis: In changes certain to be approved by parliamentarians, Russian President Vladimir Putin proposes a surprise new defence minister, nominating civilian Andrei Belousov, a former deputy prime minister who specialises in economics, for the job.

title.children: Putin to move defence chief Shoigu in surprise reshuffle

image.altText: A boy with long dark blond hair standing in a forest smiling, with his thumbs up, wears a check blue shirt.

props.synopsis: When a teenager uncovered a "critical refuge" for endangered species, it marked the start of a journey that eventually saw the parcel of land named after him.

title.children: At 14, Ned stumbled upon a 'perfect jungle'. He didn't know he would spend the next two years fighting to save it

image.altText: Dr Andy Schmulow

props.synopsis: A senior partner at PwC Australia took confidential tax information and misused it. The company sold schemes off the back of it and gloated about the millions it had made. But as the scandal dies down, the firm is winning new taxpayer-funded work and may be able to get more from December.

title.children: Back in business? PwC Australia wins new taxpayer-funded contract as government sets date for potentially more

image.altText: Picture of the book called "Same Sex parents". Two men with a boy all smiling.

props.synopsis: There is something deeply troubling about a local council trying to ban books that show the diversity of families that have legal status in our country.

title.children: The curious case of the Sydney council book ban and what happens when free speech isn't applied equally

image.altText: A smartphone displaying a folder of social media apps including Facebook, Instagram and X

props.synopsis: The SA government announces what it says is an "ambitious" first step to protect children from social media and its harmful impacts on their mental health, but one expert says a blanket ban is rarely the answer.

title.children: 'There's no time to waste': SA government looks into social media ban for children

image.altText: A lighthouse photographed in front of a pink, blue, green and yellow sky

props.synopsis: Robin Moon dropped everything to fly from Sydney to Tasmania to get a good vantage point for Saturday night's spectacular light show. She was one of many people around the country who snapped the amazing colours.

title.children: Aurora australis and borealis put on another spectacular show

image.altText: A man wearing a suit speaks to microphones

props.synopsis: The 69-year-old independent MP says he is sharing his cancer diagnosis publicly to raise awareness, adding that he plans to continue to fulfil his obligations to the state while receiving treatment.

title.children: SA upper house MP Frank Pangallo reveals stage 4 prostate cancer diagnosis

image.altText: A group of retirees at a harbour

props.synopsis: Retired home owners insist their opposition to a harbour revitalisation project in South East Queensland does not amount to NIMBYism.

title.children: Coastal home owners petition their opposition to Scarborough Harbour revitalisation

image.altText: A train on a bridge driving past apartments with larger city buildings in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia ranks among the most expensive countries in the world when it comes to the cost of public transport. But free fares might not be the solution.

title.children: This European country doesn't charge people for public transport. Could Australia do the same?
